metadata.title: Systematic Review of AI-Augmented Refactoring and Code Validation Tools in Aviation Technology Platforms
metadata.description: As aviation technology platforms become increasingly complex and software-intensive, ensuring code quality, maintainability, and compliance with stringent safety standards has become a critical priority. This systematic review examines the integration of artificial intelligence into software refactoring and code validation processes within the aviation domain. The study explores foundational concepts, evaluates real-world applications, and synthesizes academic and industry findings to assess the current landscape of AI-augmented development tools. It distinguishes between traditional and AI-driven approaches, highlighting how machine learning and predictive analytics enhance static and dynamic code analysis, formal verification, and regression testing. Through case studies from leading aerospace institutions and a review of performance metrics, the paper identifies key strengths, such as efficiency gains and automated compliance support, alongside critical limitations including explainability, generalizability, and domain-specific data scarcity. It concludes with practical and theoretical recommendations, advocating for interdisciplinary collaboration and the development of certifiable, explainable AI systems tailored to safety-critical aviation environments. This review contributes to a growing body of knowledge informing future tool development, academic inquiry, and strategic adoption within the aerospace software engineering ecosystem.

creators.name: Denis, Kisina
creators.affiliation: Cyber Reconnaissance, Inc., United States of America

keywords: AI-Augmented   Refactoring,   Code   Validation,   Aviation   Technology   Platforms,   Safety-Critical   Software, Explainable Artificial Intelligence

data.title: Systematic Review of AI-Augmented Refactoring and Code Validation Tools in Aviation Technology Platforms

metadata.title: Predictive Modeling with Temporal Disjunctive Logic
metadata.description: The integration of declarative domain knowledge, particularly complex temporal constraints, remains a significant challenge in predictive modeling. While statistical and ML models excel at pattern recognition from data, they often struggle to respect logical rules involving non-simultaneous alternatives or specific event timings needed for robust forecasting and simulation. This paper proposes leveraging TDL, a formal system designed for reasoning about temporally distributed disjunctions and featuring unique operators like temporal disjunction and unique temporal witnesses, as a specification and integration language to enhance predictive models. We explore and validate methodologies for incorporating TDL constraints into predictive workflows. Key demonstrated techniques include TDL-based feature engineering, which showed quantifiable accuracy improvements (particularly using witness features), post-hoc forecast validation and filtering to enforce logical consistency, the use of TDL rules as direct predictors exhibiting high accuracy in specific scenarios, and metric-based evaluation guided by TDL specifications. Through case studies based on simulations in finance (flight routes) and engineering (reactor control), we illustrate how TDL specifications can guide predictions, enforce logical consistency, improve model accuracy, and enhance interpretability by making temporal assumptions explicit. We conclude that TDL provides empirically validated approaches for bridging formal logical specification and data-driven predictive modeling, offering enhanced robustness, accuracy, and trustworthiness.
metadata.notes:
Repository Code for Experiments

The software developed for this study (TDL-protosimulator} is currently under active development and will be made available at https://github.com/sandner-art/SC-Temporal-Disjunctive-Logic. It is scheduled for public release upon completion of unit testing phase, and contains the experiments for TDL papers.

This work is part of the '100 Scientific Visions' initiative, exploring the use of AI in scientific research (idea brainstorming, validation, experiment design, calculation, reference and resource research, analysis, manuscript preparation and editing). The project aims to investigate methodology of effective use of AI tools in a transparent way. The author acknowledges the assistance of LLM Models (types of custom trained models if used are referenced in repositories) and AI Systems in research, evaluation, coding, manuscript drafting, and other manuscript preparation tasks.

data.title: Predictive Modeling with Temporal Disjunctive Logic

metadata.title: Temporal Disjunctive Logic for Non-Simultaneous Reasoning
metadata.description:
Non-simultaneous disjunctions—conditions where alternatives hold at different times—are common yet challenging to interpret using standard temporal logics. This paper introduces Temporal Disjunctive Logic (TDL), a framework designed to represent and reason about such patterns directly.

We present TPL-BO, a core TDL formalism built on Point Temporal Logic with bounded operators for past and future events within a temporal bound k. Within TPL-BO, we define precise semantics for the symmetric Temporal Disjunction operator, capturing alternatives across past, present, and future, derive its key properties, and establish a valid Temporal Disjunction Elimination deductive property.

We enhance expressiveness through an extension analyzing selective witness operators (minimal future Fmin_k and maximal past Pmax_k) for identifying unique minimal future or maximal past events within a bound k.

Computationally, TDL satisfiability is PSPACE-complete. We demonstrate feasible model checking performance via prototype experiments (TDL-protosimulator), analyzing the effects of memoization, formula structure, and temporal bounds. Illustrative examples drawing from synthetic and imported data experiments confirm TDL's practical potential for specification, verification, and analysis within simulations.

This foundational paper introduces the core concepts and utility of TDL.
metadata.notes:
Repository Info (Code for Experiments)

The software developed for this study (TDL-protosimulator} is currently under active development and will be made available at https://github.com/sandner-art/SC-Temporal-Disjunctive-Logic. It is scheduled for public release upon completion of unit testing phase, and contains the experiments for TDL papers.

This work is part of the '100 Scientific Visions' initiative, exploring the use of AI in scientific research (idea brainstorming, validation, experiment design, calculation, reference and resource research, analysis, manuscript preparation and editing). The project aims to investigate methodology of effective use of AI tools in a transparent way. The author acknowledges the assistance of LLM Models (types of custom trained models if used are referenced in repositories) and AI Systems in research, evaluation, coding, manuscript drafting, and other manuscript preparation tasks.

data.title: Temporal Disjunctive Logic for Non-Simultaneous Reasoning

metadata.title: "INTEGRATING 4C SKILLS: A KEY TO EFFECTIVE ENGLISH TEACHING"
metadata.description: In the modern world, teaching English requires more than traditional methods. The integration of 4C skills — Communication, Collaboration, Critical Thinking, and Creativity — is crucial for developing language learners who are competent, adaptive, and ready for future challenges. This paper explores how the 4C framework transforms English classrooms into interactive, engaging, and student-centered environments. It also discusses the benefits of applying the 4Cs in language teaching and offers practical strategies for implementation.

creators.name: Qurbonova Dilnoza Allanazarovna
creators.affiliation: 2nd year student of PhD, Department of English Linguistics, The National University of Uzbekistan named after Mirzo Ulugbek

keywords: 4C skills, English language teaching, communication, collaboration, creativity, critical thinking, 21st-century education.
references: 1.	Brookfield, S. D. (2012). Teaching for critical thinking: Tools and techniques to help students question their assumptions. Jossey-Bass.

2.	Johnson, D. W., & Johnson, R. T. (2009). An educational psychology success story: Social interdependence theory and cooperative learning. Educational Researcher, 38(5), 365-379. https://doi.org/10.3102/0034654308325178

metadata.title: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE IN EDUCATION
metadata.description: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the integration of online and hybrid teaching strategies. Educators began adopting artificial intelligence (AI) tools to support student learning outcomes. However, these technologies were unfamiliar to many, highlighting a need for teachers to acquire digital competencies that align with AI integration.This study discusses the challenges and possibilities presented by AI in education.

creators.name: Israilova Dilkhumor Sherzod kizi
creators.affiliation: doctoral student Uzbekistan state world languages university

keywords: AI technologies,educational tools, digital competencies, opportunities, challenges.
references: Ahmad, A., Chen, Y., & Zhang, L. (2022). Personalized learning with AI: Opportunities and challenges. *International Journal of Artificial Intelligence in Education*, 32(1), 67–84.
Akgun, S., & Greenhow, C. (2021). Ethical concerns in AI education: A literature review. *Computers & Education*, 174, 104304.

metadata.title: Virtual Orientation Tools (VOTj): Fiji plugins for object centering and alignment - Micropublication
metadata.description:
This short publication describes a set of Fiji plugins for object-based image alignement, and object-centering.  

Originally published in microPublication https://www.micropublication.org/journals/biology/micropub-biology-001221

The plugins can be installed by activating the VOTj update site in Fiji.

The plugins source code (jython) is available in the following VOTj Github repo .

grants.title: Training European Experts in Inflammation: from the molecular players to animal models and the bedside
